semantic_identifier: 2262584 - Westgate Alloy Works - sales_call - Discussion with Levi Ray

hierarchy.meeting_title: 2262584 - Westgate Alloy Works - sales_call - Discussion with Levi Ray

sections.text: James Choi: Hi Levi, good to see you again. Thanks for making time for a quick follow-up. Last time you mentioned you liked the idea of turning your inbound interest into more consistent action in the CRM—does that still feel like the priority for Westgate Alloy Works right now?
Levi Ray: Yeah, it’s still a priority. We’re getting leads, but we’re not always fast, and it’s hard to tell what’s real versus noise.

James Choi: That’s exactly the gap Sales_Accelerator is built for—taking what you already have in Salesforce or HubSpot and turning it into “do this next” guidance and a cleaner forecast. For today, I’d love to focus on two things only: the sales_forecast piece, and the initiation recommendations for inbound speed-to-lead. Does that work?
Levi Ray: Sure, but I’ll tell you upfront—tools that rely on our CRM data usually fall apart because our data isn’t perfect.

James Choi: Totally fair. Let’s start with the forecast because it’s where the value is easiest to quantify. Sales_Accelerator creates an opportunity and pipeline forecast that combines stage data with activity signals—emails, calls, meetings—and cycle-time benchmarks. And if you’re using Customer_Analyzer, it can also weight the forecast using fit scores so your Tier 1 inbound doesn’t get treated the same as a marginal lead. The output is commit, best-case, and pipeline views, and it’s explainable—like “this slipped because stage age is high and there’s no next meeting scheduled.”

Levi Ray: The explainable part is good. But our stages are stale. Reps don’t update next steps consistently, and close dates are… honestly kind of made up until the last minute. If your forecast is built on that, it’s going to be wrong.

James Choi: That’s the most common blocker, and I don’t want to gloss over it. The reason we include activity signals is specifically to reduce dependence on “perfect CRM hygiene.” If a deal is in Stage 3 but there hasn’t been a meeting, email reply, or call connection in 21 days, Sales_Accelerator will flag that as risk. Conversely, if the close date is optimistic but there’s a next meeting booked and consistent engagement, the forecast driver will reflect that momentum.
Levi Ray: But doesn’t that just create more alerts? We already have enough “nudge” tools. Our team ignores them.

James Choi: Great point—alert fatigue is real. The way Sales_Accelerator avoids spamming is by focusing on a smaller set of drivers and tying alerts to specific actions. For example, instead of “Deal at risk,” it’s “No customer meeting scheduled; recommend scheduling within 7 days based on typical cycle time for deals this size.” It’s meant to be actionable, not just noise.
Levi Ray: We’d still need reps to trust it. And if it’s wrong early on because our CRM is messy, they’ll tune it out.

James Choi: That’s why most teams start with a narrow rollout. For Westgate, the obvious first use case is the growth team’s inbound speed-to-lead. Sales_Accelerator can prioritize high-fit inbound leads—using Customer_Analyzer fit score—and recommend the best first response message, then track whether faster first touch correlates with higher win rate. It’s a contained motion with clear metrics: response time, meeting set rate, and conversion to SQL.
Levi Ray: The inbound part interests me more than forecasting, honestly. Forecasting is important, but we’re not going to change our process overnight.

James Choi: That’s fine. On inbound, the “best-next-action” is very concrete: “This lead is Tier 1, respond within X minutes, here’s a message tailored to their profile.” Then you can see a dashboard that correlates first-touch speed with downstream outcomes so it’s not just a gut feel.

Levi Ray: We already have routing and sequences in our sales engagement tool. So what’s net-new here? Because if this is just another layer telling us to follow up, it’s not going to survive internally.

James Choi: Net-new is prioritization plus explanation. Your engagement tool can send sequences, but it doesn’t typically know which inbound is highest-fit based on your ICP and positioning, and it doesn’t close the loop to outcomes in an explainable way. Sales_Accelerator sits above the stack: it consumes the fit score from Customer_Analyzer, watches the activity signals, and recommends the first touch and follow-up sequence that historically works for similar accounts.
Levi Ray: Maybe. But again—our CRM is inconsistent, and we don’t have clean historical data to train “what works.” We’ve changed messaging a lot.

James Choi: That’s a fair concern. We don’t require years of pristine history to start. For inbound prioritization, you can begin with fit-tier plus basic signals like source and firmographic match, then iterate as more data comes in. The early win is usually just stopping the team from spending prime time on low-fit inbound while high-fit sits untouched.
Levi Ray: We also have a really specific sales cycle. We’re not a standard SaaS motion. We’re manufacturing—deal stages don’t map neatly to “emails and meetings.”

James Choi: Understood. The forecasting driver set is configurable—stage conversion and cycle-time benchmarks can be based on your segments and your reality. But I don’t want to oversell it; if your team isn’t logging meetings or using the calendar integration, you’d lose signal.

Levi Ray: Right now we’re not consistent. Some reps log everything, some log nothing. And I’m worried your system will just punish the reps who are honest and reward the ones who don’t update anything.

James Choi: That’s a legitimate risk. If the underlying activity capture isn’t consistent, forecasting and risk flags can get distorted. We can pull activity from email/calendar automatically, but if your org policies or permissions don’t allow that, it gets harder.
Levi Ray: Yeah, IT has been strict lately. Anything that reads email or calendar gets a long security review. That’s another constraint.

James Choi: Thanks for saying that. If email/calendar access is a long cycle, then the fastest path would be the inbound prioritization using Customer_Analyzer fit scores and CRM fields you already have—source, form data, lead status—and then keep the forecasting piece for later once activity capture is approved.
Levi Ray: Even that… we’d still need reps to update lead status correctly. And they don’t.

James Choi: If lead status is unreliable, that will definitely affect the reporting and could mis-prioritize. We can mitigate with rules—like “new inbound from Tier 1 always gets a task created and escalated if untouched”—but you’re right that it’s still dependent on some hygiene.
Levi Ray: That’s kind of the theme. Everything depends on us doing the basics better. And we’ve tried to fix that with process and training, but adoption is the hard part.
James Choi: If I’m hearing you right, the value is there, but the org readiness—data hygiene, integrations, adoption—might not be there yet to justify a new layer.
Levi Ray: Exactly. I like the concept, and I can see how it could help, but I don’t want to buy something and then spend six months fighting our own process.

James Choi: That’s reasonable. The next step I’d normally propose is a short pilot focused on inbound speed-to-lead for one segment, with a very small set of signals and one measurable outcome. But if you’re saying adoption and IT reviews are headwinds right now, we might be forcing timing.
Levi Ray: Yeah. We’re also in the middle of a CRM cleanup project. Leadership wants that done first, then we’ll look at forecasting tools.

James Choi: Got it. In that case, rather than pushing a pilot, would it be helpful if I sent you a lightweight readiness checklist—like the minimum CRM fields and process steps that make Sales_Accelerator actually work—so your cleanup effort aligns with it? Then we can revisit once you’re through that project.
Levi Ray: That would be helpful. But I can’t commit to a timeline. Could be a quarter, could be longer.

James Choi: No problem. I’ll send the checklist and a short summary of what we discussed—specifically the inbound prioritization and the forecast drivers—and you can use it internally. How about we tentatively check back in, say, six weeks, and you can tell me where the cleanup and IT review stand?
Levi Ray: Sure, set something up. Just keep it tentative.
James Choi: Will do. Appreciate the candor, Levi. I’ll follow up with that doc today and a couple of examples of the inbound prioritization view so you can see what it would look like for Westgate.
Levi Ray: Sounds good. Thanks, James.
